docs.section_name: Technology; Education; New York and Region
docs.lead_paragraph: Gerard Guarniero spent eighth grade using a Braille slate -- an eight-inch metal device that looks like a ruler with four rows of stencil spaces for lettering. He would place paper between the two sides and use a short pointer to punch holes in the paper. It would take him three or four times as long to write the same paper as his sighted classmates. Some 30 years later, when Pratik Patel was in eighth grade at Intermediate School 237, a mainstream school in Queens, he could simply type his essays on a keyboard. He sent his work to a Braille printer, where a sheet with raised lettering would come out in minutes.
docs.abstract: Dozens of students gather at retirement party in Queens honoring their middle school teacher, Betty Salz, who has taught blind students in New York City for more than 40 years; they remark on how personal data assistants, word processing and Internet have altered ways blind students do schoolwork (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Language does not come naturally to machines. Unlike humans, computers cannot easily distinguish between, say, a river bank and a savings bank. Satire and jokes? Algorithms have great trouble with that. Irony? Wordplay? Cultural context? Forget it. That human edge in decoding what things mean is what a computer scientist turned entrepreneur, Luis von Ahn, is betting on. His start-up, Duolingo, which opened to the public on Tuesday, proposes to put armies of language learners to work translating text on the Web.
docs.abstract: Online foreign language translation start-up Duolingo will harness the power of its users; expects human element to overcome obstacles computer algorithms face in translating the more subtle aspects of language. Photo (M)2

docs.lead_paragraph: A researcher who co-wrote a paper in the 1990s on a crucial artificial intelligence technique feels overlooked by today’s stars in the field.
docs.abstract: Jurgen Schmidhuber, co-director of Dalle Molle Institute for Artificial Intelligence Research in Switzerland, says he feels frustrated and disrespected by certain researchers who fail to acknowledge his groundbreaking contributions to artificial intelligence; had co-written paper in 1990s that led to rapid progress in field.
docs.snippet: A researcher who co-wrote a paper in the 1990s on a crucial artificial intelligence technique feels overlooked by today’s stars in the field....

headline.main: When A.I. Matures, It May Call Jürgen Schmidhuber ‘Dad’
